qas.question: Presbyterianism is based on this type of tradition, what is it?
Confessional churches express this form of confession, what is it named?
What is not a sole matter individually in a confessional church?
How is theology carried out in a confessional church?

answers.text: by the community as a whole

qas.question: In which way do nonconfessional churches express their faith?
Which is solely an individual matter in confessional churches?
In which type of churches is theology carried out by individuals?
The individual understanding of theology is expressed during what?
The fact that Presbyterianism is historically a theology has how many implications?

context: Presbyterianism is historically a <a0_0>confessional tradition<a0_0/>. This has <b8_0>two<b8_0/> implications. The obvious one is that confessional churches express their faith in the form of "<a1_0><b4_0>confessions of faith<b4_0/><a1_0/>," which have some level of authoritative status. However this is based on a more subtle point: In <b6_0>confessional churches<b6_0/>, <a2_0><b5_0>theology<b5_0/><a2_0/> is not solely an individual matter. While individuals are encouraged to understand Scripture, and may challenge the current institutional understanding, theology is carried out <a3_0>by the community as a whole<a3_0/>. It is this community understanding of theology that is expressed in <b7_0>confessions<b7_0/>.
